articles.headline: In Iraqi’s Shoe-Hurling Protest, Arabs Find a Hero. (It’s Not Bush.)
articles.snippet: The Iraqi journalist who threw shoes at President Bush has stirred emotions across the Arab world.
articles.abstract: The Iraqi journalist who threw shoes at President Bush has stirred emotions across the Arab world.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Calling someone the “son of a shoe” is one of the worst insults in Iraq. But the lowly shoe and the Iraqi who threw both of his at President Bush, with widely admired aim, were embraced around the Arab world on Monday as symbols of rage at a still unpopular war.
articles.byline: By Timothy Williams and Abeer Mohammed

articles.headline: Caroline Kennedy Is Seeking Seat Held by Clinton
articles.snippet: Caroline Kennedy is launching a public effort to demonstrate that she has both the ability and the stomach to perform the job.
articles.abstract: Caroline Kennedy is launching a public effort to demonstrate that she has both the ability and the stomach to perform the job.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALBANY  Caroline Kennedy, the deeply private daughter of America’s most storied political dynasty, will seek the United States Senate seat in New York being vacated by Hillary Rodham Clinton.

articles.headline: Top Court Lets Smokers Sue for Fraud
articles.snippet: Companies that marketed “light” cigarettes may be sued, the Supreme Court ruled in a 5-to-4 decision.
articles.abstract: Companies that marketed “light” cigarettes may be sued, the Supreme Court ruled in a 5-to-4 decision.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Tobacco companies that marketed “light” cigarettes may be sued for fraud, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday in a 5-to-4 decision that will bolster dozens of lawsuits claiming billions of dollars in damages.

articles.headline: Big Oil Projects Put in Jeopardy by Fall in Prices
articles.snippet: Price cuts are welcome at the pump, but delays may cut future supplies, setting the stage for another price surge.
articles.abstract: Price cuts are welcome at the pump, but delays may cut future supplies, setting the stage for another price surge.
articles.lead_paragraph: From the plains of North Dakota to the deep waters of Brazil, dozens of major oil and gas projects have been suspended or canceled in recent weeks as companies scramble to adjust to the collapse in energy markets.

articles.headline: Wall St. Fraud Leaves Charities Reeling
articles.snippet: Around the country, nonprofits are reeling from the Madoff scandal.
articles.abstract: Around the country, nonprofits are reeling from the Madoff scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Jeanne Levy-Church created the JEHT Foundation in 2002 to promote justice, equality, human dignity and tolerance, she tapped into investments run by Bernard L. Madoff.

articles.headline: Dell Trails Its Rivals in the Worst of Times
articles.snippet: Michael S. Dell’s weariness toward questions about what has gone wrong at his company, once the world’s largest PC vendor, is understandable.
articles.abstract: Michael S. Dell’s weariness toward questions about what has gone wrong at his company, once the world’s largest PC vendor, is understandable.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROUND ROCK, Tex.  Michael S. Dell has grown tired of discussing his company’s reinvention.

articles.headline: Global Car Industry Fearful for Detroit
articles.snippet: There are growing concerns that the automakers’ problems in the United States will weigh down their more successful units in Europe, Asia and Latin America.
articles.abstract: There are growing concerns that the automakers’ problems in the United States will weigh down their more successful units in Europe, Asia and Latin America.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUNICH  For years, the overseas operations of Ford and General Motors helped buoy Detroit when times were difficult in the United States.

articles.headline: In Blagojevich Case, Is It a Crime, or Just Talk?
articles.snippet: The tapes of Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich talking about benefiting from his Senate pick may fall into a legal gray area.
articles.abstract: The tapes of Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich talking about benefiting from his Senate pick may fall into a legal gray area.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the United States attorney in Chicago, announced the arrest of the Illinois governor, Rod R. Blagojevich, Mr. Fitzgerald said he had acted to halt a political crime spree that included what he called an “appalling” effort to sell off the Senate seat vacated by President-elect Barack Obama.

articles.headline: How the Fed Reached Out to Lehman
articles.snippet: Officials who had refused to risk taxpayers’ money on Lehman Brothers before it collapsed did just that after it collapsed. The mystery loan is one piece of a larger puzzle.
articles.abstract: Officials who had refused to risk taxpayers’ money on Lehman Brothers before it collapsed did just that after it collapsed. The mystery loan is one piece of a larger puzzle.

articles.headline: Schools Chief From Chicago Is Cabinet Pick
articles.snippet: Arne Duncan is known for taking tough steps to improve schools while maintaining respectful ties with unions.
articles.abstract: Arne Duncan is known for taking tough steps to improve schools while maintaining respectful ties with unions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Arne Duncan, the Chicago schools superintendent known for taking tough steps to improve schools while maintaining respectful relations with teachers and their unions, is President-elect Barack Obama’s choice as secretary of education, Democratic officials said Monday.

articles.headline: Inquiry Finds No Signs Family Aided Madoff
articles.snippet: Investigators have found no evidence so far that members of Bernard L. Madoff’s family aided in what may be the largest financial fraud in history, according to a person briefed on the case.
articles.abstract: Investigators have found no evidence so far that members of Bernard L. Madoff’s family aided in what may be the largest financial fraud in history, according to a person briefed on the case.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal investigators have found no evidence so far that members of Bernard L. Madoff’s family helped him carry out what may be the largest financial fraud in history, according to a person briefed on the case.
articles.byline: By Alex Berenson and Diana B. Henriques
